"A total of 336 schools in South Korea have temporarily shut down or postponed the start of the new semester due to fears of the spread of the new coronavirus, government data showed Monday.    According to the Ministry of Education, 245 kindergartens, 53 elementary schools, 21 middle schools, 16 high schools and one special education school nationwide have halted school operations or delayed reopening after winter vacation as of 9 a.m. as part of emergency measures to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.    Elementary and secondary schools here usually restart in the last week of January or the first week of February after a month-long winter vacation.    (...) The ministry decided over the weekend to allow schools in areas presumed to be vulnerable to the viral disease, or where a confirmed case is reported or a carrier is found to have traveled, to choose temporary closure after prior consultations with regional educational authorities.    In Gyeonggi Province that surrounds Seoul, educational authorities in Suwon and Bucheon ordered all kindergartens and elementary and secondary schools in their jurisdiction to close for a week.    Authorities in Goyang, also in Gyeonggi Province, recommended closures for all its kindergartens for one week.    In Seoul, a total of nine schools, including three elementary schools, two middle schools and three high schools, remained closed as of Monday morning.    In Gunsan, a North Jeolla Province city where a confirmed case of the new coronavirus was reported, all kindergartens and elementary and secondary schools were ordered shut for two weeks."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200330180640/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/weeks-of-school-closure-in-south-korea-a-home-based-working-mums-nightmare

"South Korea said Tuesday it will be postponing the new school year for another two weeks as it fights COVID-19 group infections that have occurred at churches, hospitals and even Zumba classes.  Under the measure, the new school year at kindergartens and elementary, middle and high schools nationwide will begin on April 6, five weeks later than in normal years, according to the education ministry.  Child care centers, which provide care for toddlers and children up to 7 years old, will also close for another two weeks and open April 6, the health ministry said.  "The government judges that while the COVID-19 (outbreak) has entered a downtrend, it is early to let down our guard. It aims to again encourage people to actively take part in 'social distancing' with the school year postponement," the ministry said in a press release."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200330181248/http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20200317000686

From April 3 2020, all patients classified as suspected cases and Patients Under Investigation (PUI) may get tested.     Suspected case: A person who develops a fever or respiratory symptoms (coughing, difficulty breathing, etc.) within 14 days of coming into contact with a confirmed patient.    Persons under investigation: A person who is suspected of having the COVID-19 virus as per doctor’s diagnosis of pneumonia of unknown causes.    ? A person who develops a fever (37.5? and above) or respiratory symptoms (coughing, difficulty breathing, etc.) within 14 days of travelling overseas  ? The Ministry of Health and Welfare announces their 4th supplementary budget project with an emergency welfare support for families whose income has decreased by more than 25% due to Covid-19. Online applications will open October 12th and in-person applications will open October 19th until end of the month.      Additionally, it will benefit people whose business incomes (sales) has decreased by 25% or more, and those who were unemployed since February.    The amount received will also depend on the number of household members, spouses can be either included or excluded (if it results in unfavorable cases). Only foreigners married to Korean citizens can be included in the household members.     Archived web: https://archive.vn/VzBHE

"South Korea's education ministry on Sunday said it will ease attendance caps for schools after health authorities decided to enforce the lowest level of social distancing measures.    Schools around the nation are required to operate with antivirus limits amid the coronavirus pandemic. Currently, attendance is capped at one-third in elementary and middle schools, and two-thirds in high schools.    But starting Oct. 19, the attendance cap for all schools will be set at two-thirds, Seoul's education ministry said.    (...) The latest move is in line with health authorities' decision to lower the country's social distancing scheme to Level 1 from Monday in the three-tier system.    Schools that have small classroom populations and are located in regions with relatively small virus caseloads can further ease the cap to accommodate more students, the ministry said. However, schools in the greater Seoul area and have big classroom population are strictly required to follow the cap.    The ministry said schools can decide their class operation schedules depending on their situation, and can expand in-class activities by staggering school hours, or running different time tables for each class. Such eased rules will allow some schools to have full-time in-class activities daily, according to the ministry."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201125223711/http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20201011000252

Note: After the government tightened restrictions in August because of the church outbreak and in late September because of a national holiday, it loosened them again in October.     In May and June, after the first implementation of the “distancing in daily life” strategy, multiple outbreaks occurred in the Seoul area, with clusters from bars and warehouses. As a result, Seoul resumed more strict distancing guidelines until daily case counts were below ten. During the second spike in August, the entire country moved up to Level 2. These restrictions were eased in most of the country on October 12. It tightened again in November, and in December in Seoul, but the recommendations remained for the whole country.    See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210504070117/https://ourworldindata.org/covid-exemplar-south-korea

Starting today, October 12, stage 1 of social distancing comes into effect in compliance to personal quarantine rules such as “wearing a mask, keeping a safe distance, and washing hands.”     Gatherings of more than 50 people indoors and more than 100 people outdoors ban is lifted for the general public. However, temporary gatherings are limited to one person per (4m)^2 of facility area. Moreover, facilities such as restaurants, wedding halls, and academic institutions are recommended to refrain from gatherings of 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors.     Churches are allowed to operate in 30% of total capacity, but meals after service are prohibited.    High-risk facilities such as clubs and pubs are allowed to open with mandatory rules such as wearing face masks and managing a thorough list of visitors, restrictions on the number of people allowed follows the one person per (4m)^2 of facility area. A three-stage system is designed by assuming life quarantine (stage 1), regional outbreaks (1.5, 2nd stage), and national outbreaks (2.5, 3rd stages), and up to stage 2, which is a local epidemic, steps centered around the outbreak zone. Currently, Step 1 is the status quo, with metropolitan areas having less than 100 cases on a daily average, other areas having less than 30, and Gangwon and Jeju less than 10.     At Step 1, 2/3 capacity of overcrowded schools is recommended.	    https://web.archive.org/web/20201109103001/http://ncov.mohw.go.kr/tcmBoardView.do?brdId=&brdGubun=&dataGubun=&ncvContSeq=360602&contSeq=360602&board_id=&gubun=ALL

On December 8th, the Korean government secures up to 44 million vaccines for COVID-19. The government announced that it will pre-purchase overseas vaccines for up to 44 million people through COVAX Facility (for about 10 million people) and global vaccine companies (for about 34 million people). The pre-purchased vaccine is expected to be introduced in stages from the first quarter of 2021 (February and March); however, the later distribution may vary depending on ongoing clinical trial results and close monitoring.     The elderly, vulnerable groups, and essential service personnel such as health care professionals  will be the first in line to receive the vaccine as they account for about 36 million people.    https://archive.vn/KOalT

Religious facilities must comply with strict social distancing guidelines during Christmas and New Year. Participation capacity is limited to 20% in both metropolitan and non-metropolitan areas.     https://archive.vn/b8PqF

On December 10th 2020, the Ministry of Justice has implemented a lodging report system for short-term visitors who are staying in Korea for 90 days or less to identify and monitor their location. When staying at lodging facilities, they must present their passports and travel certificates for record purposes at the local immigration/foreigner offices. If the visitor does not provide the required documents to the lodging facility or provides false information, a fine of not more than 500,000 won (~USD 500) will be imposed.    https://archive.vn/b8PqF

On December 10th, the government announced yesterday that the prime minister presided over the quarantine situation in the metropolitan area and plans to strengthen the quarantine regulations and maximize response capabilities such as expanding epidemiological investigations, diagnostic tests, and establishing "special situation rooms" for Covid-19 response in the metropolitan area.

Medical personnel dealing directly with the treatment of COVID-19 such as nurses treating severely ill patients will receive a temporary risk allowance of about 3 million won per month (~USD 2,750) and the night shift pay will be doubled when treating critically ill patients.     https://archive.vn/AcZx3

Emergency living expenses, which are paid up to 1 million won (based on households of 4 or more), to households in crisis whose income has declined due to COVID-19, will be paid to about 150,000 households subject to secondary payment from December 18 (Fri). The Ministry of Health and Welfare (Minister Park Neung-hoo) announced that emergency living expenses for households in crisis will be paid for the first time on December 4 and the second from December 18. Through this, emergency living expenses were paid to 350,000 low-income households who were not eligible for other COVID-19 support projects, such as unemployed people, small business owners in traditional markets, and daily workers due to COVID-19 damages.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201226072155/http://ncov.mohw.go.kr/tcmBoardView.do?brdId=&brdGubun=&dataGubun=&ncvContSeq=362117&contSeq=362117&board_id=140&gubun=BDJ

South Korea said on December 23, 2020, it will suspend flights leaving for and arriving from United Kingdom until the end of the year (December 31) over concerns about a new strain of the novel coronavirus. The measure takes effect immediately, according to health authorities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201226075508/https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20201223004400320

"Domestically, South Korea’s success inspired confidence, and was even given a name – “K-quarantine” – a political PR-buzzword encompassing everything from digital surveillance and mass testing to strict social distancing measures and tight border control. The government also published an 88-page guidebook on how to “flatten the curve” using technology instead of lockdowns.  Not all headlines outside South Korea were positive. Questions about privacy and the balance between individual rights and public health were often mentioned. The issue was also raised by local media and the country’s own human rights watchdog."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210128003006/https://www.newstatesman.com/world/asia/2021/01/how-south-korea-s-covid-19-success-faltered

"... [T]he use of emergency smartphone alerts that were deemed too revealing when disclosing information – sometimes personal – of nearby cases to mobile phones within the same vicinity. But, by and large, this never caused significant public opposition at home. That authorities had access to personal information such as credit card records for contact tracing was even less of an issue, largely considered acceptable if it meant benefitting society."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210128003006/https://www.newstatesman.com/world/asia/2021/01/how-south-korea-s-covid-19-success-faltered

"Moon said South Korea will begin its Covid-19 vaccination program next month (February). Although it’s later than many advanced economies, South Korea has posted relatively low infection and death rates after it slowed the virus’s initial spread without a lockdown, relying instead on rapid testing and contact-tracing to mitigate flareups."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210128003006/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-27/south-korea-sees-economy-rebounding-to-pre-covid-levels-by-june

The economy is going strong.  "South Korea ended the pandemic year of 2020 with a 1% contraction in gross domestic product, likely to be the smallest among OECD members.
